Healthcare isn't terrible, but you would think working for a hospital that has their own insurance plan that it would cover a lot more.

review_title: Good place to get experience and move on
pros: Insurance is ok, always short handed so you get to do lots of different things
cons: Low Pay for Epic Analysts, and depending on your tier, they are solely responsible for upgrades, maintenance, requests, tickets, new build, projects and passing the information along to the training team for at least one module if not multiple. Always short handed so it is hard to get anything done, pay is much lower than other places in Oregon and does not correlate with the expanded high level responsibility in comparison organizations. HR has total and complete control over pay scales and are secretive about their compensation research process, only recently have they given any credit for past experience, yet they still only account for in system experience not outside the org or education/internships. Promotions are arbitrary and the time it takes to advance completely depends on the manager. Recent reorg complicates matters further and deeply segregates teams and has reduced collaboration between groups and has decimated the traditional model of separate teams for each module and tried to push all analysts towards be generalists. You will likely not get certified if not already, proficiencies only here, they don’t like to pay for it unless you are a design analyst, those doing all the troubleshooting and maintenance are not treated well. A new restructure on the horizon has many people on edge. Half the team has quit and moved on over the last year and half. Insurance costs more yearly with reduced benefits, and you only have the option of Samaritan plans. Salaries employees have a maximum raise of 3% per year that you have to work your butt off to get, no cost of living raise in over 4 years, and no bonuses, but hey you might get a free fruit platter from Safeway if you go in during the short window the coupon is good for!

pros: Excellent clinical experience.  You will get to do it all as a pharmacist.  There are many pharmacist driven protocols.  The medical team likes pharmacist input.  You do get breaks/lunches and the rest of the medical staff (docs and nurses) are basically good.  You can transfer into other departments
cons: There is very high turnover of techs.  Don't expect them to do much except fight amongst themselves.  There is very little oversight of techs and mgt doesn't want to hear about it.  Speaking of management - they basically don't want to hear from pharmacists at all.  If you have any issue you basically have to go to HR to resolve it.  There philosophy is 'our way or the highway'.  If you have an easy going personality then you'll be ok but if you think just because you're an RPH that they will listen to you then forget it (including about legal issues involving the board..  don't opine).

review_title: Kind, hardworking employees devalued by fiefdom managers
pros:
-most employees are kind and hardworking
-benefits are good overall
-the company supports a healthy lifestyle
-there is not the ego among providers and doctors that is often present at larger institutions 
-the people taking care of patients are very committed to patient care
cons:
-managers have little management skill or training, and seem to have obtained their job by being an insider or friend with someone high up, not by merit
-management doesn’t really understand what providers do, so they make decisions that hurt their profitability and their patients
- management doesn’t solicit feedback from the people on the ground, and doesn’t communicate with them, either 
-there are little fiefdoms throughout the organization, but no unifying leadership. As a result, the right hand doesn’t know what the left hand is doing 
- weak leaders are threatened by new talent, so there are no opportunities for advancement unless you know someone at the top

review_title: Samaritan Company Culture is the  Best!
job_title: Document Management Clerk in Corvallis, OR
pros: Samaritan onboarding is really great.  Management takes the time to give you a guided tour, introduce you to others in your department, and HR makes sure you have a clear understanding of company wide policies.
cons: Communication between departments remains a fly in the ointment at Samaritan.  Within departments it's great, with one on one meetings with your manager, but when there is a problem that needs resolved between departments there just isn't a clear enough understanding between the two as to how each department's functionality affects the other.  I understand that Samaritan is actively working to rectify this, and that's why I loved working there.

review_title: Solid Company, broad range, but definitely growing
pros:
The rapidly changing climate of healthcare in the US has sparked some significant changes in the way hospitals and health related organizations do business. SHS has done an amazing job at responding to those changes.

They're a medium to large organization that is trying to break down department/hospital silos.

Large enough to have plenty of lateral movement if you find you're not interested in the type of job you're currently in.

Excellent benefits package.
cons:
Leadership at times is too averse to negative outcomes. For fear of making the wrong decision, no decision is made; this leads to paralysis by analysis.

Although some are picking up the ball and running with it, it is typically after the quarterback has set the ball down on the field and sat down to have his/her lunch.

pros:
Mission based not for profit, constantly seeking ways to serve the community.  
Huge employer for area: 5 hospitals, many dozens of clinics in three counties.  
Usually room for advancement or at minimum transfer should you get bored with your job and ready for something new.  
Education and wellness benefits.  Lots of continuing education opportunities in house.
cons: Size has its drawbacks.  Change can be slooooow in coming.  Left fans sometimes hasn't even met right hand yet:  confusion can reign.  Because of the layers of admin (and it's very hierarchical) your experience will be directly reliant on your immediate team and the effectiveness of your manager in advocating for your team needs.

pros:
Benefits are above average.
Pay scale is above average.
Great doctors who care about their patients
Clinical staff is supportive to each other and works hard to provide excellent patient care
cons:
Management has an adversarial relationship with clinical staff members including the physicians. 
Needs a new/refurbished facility.
Management fosters an negative environment of punitive measures towards staff when a system problem is brought to their attention instead of working together for a solution.  
Management hides serious issues that compromise patient safety and threatens to fire employees if they discuss these issues openly.

pros: There is always someone there to help, stafff are friendly, clean, professional. They care about their employess and  not only on the job. They care about the community. They keep their grounds immaculate. They provide fine wages and compensation packages. Clinic managers are highly qualified. Doctors and nursing staff work hard to mainain educational goals.
cons: Poor flexibility regarding hourly schedules for those who need full time work but can't work five days per week.

review_title: Great place to work, ethical company focused on health
job_title: IS Training Program Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: As a healthcare organization, the company focuses strongly on the community.  Many employees know each other and share activities at work.  Healthy lifestyle incentives include Wellness Dollars which can be used for health club memberships and other things.  A concerted effort to upgrade all major IT systems was undergone over the past two years.
cons: Small town environment can be challenging to some.  Car travel can be required for some positions, since the five hospitals span 3 counties.

pros:
Decent pay for the area
Decent medical, dental, vision benefits
Relatively stable environment
Community based and focused
Fantastic opportunities for growth
Excellent career starter organization
Strong focus on internal hiring
Strong focus on employee skill development
Strong support for education and training
1-3% annual raises
Depending on department - management can be very compassionate, caring, hard working and admirable.
cons:
Better pay and benefits offered elsewhere, but not in the immediate area
Occasional bouts of poor employee retention
HR processes such as hiring, promotions and conflict resolution is slow
Nearly routine org changes
Somewhat worrying level of employee terminations at times
Organization values are admirable but don't always match up with quality of services

review_title: Good place to work, but still recovering from 2008
job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Corvallis, OR
pros:
Great location in Corvallis
Friendly environment
Pay is in line with the area
Stood by their workforce in 2008 and avoided layoffs
cons:
Understaffed and very hard to sign on new employees currently
All director's positions in IT were cut with no warning and no explanation which created a tense environment.
Facilities are cramped, everyone is in a cube

pros: Good company to work for in regards to benefits and peers, union which is a big plus!
cons: Could use to be more supportive to employees who are going through something very difficult and personal rather than shaming and forcing a resignation

pros: Amazing work environment, the people are very friendly and great to work with. Plenty of opportunities to advance your career. Great work-life balance.
cons: Benefits are okay but can definitely be improved. It is a non-profit, so don't expect any sort of major bonuses or great benefits.

pros: Great Opportunity, training offered to keep your skills up to date. Many co-workers who are very friendly and offer excellent support.
cons: Some of the managers are not what I would call top of the line. They do have some very good managers, who let you know when you are doing well and when you could use some guidance.

review_title: Pay is decent but they treat employees poorly
pros: good pay and okay benefits
cons: The higher ups treat clerical staff like trash and they will get rid of anyone due to pettiness or pay cuts and come up with a sad excuse instead of telling the employee it was due to pay cuts. They praise employees who mess up allthe time and get rid of the good ones.

pros: Great nurses. Failed potential otherwise
cons:
If you value your career, your livelihood & your license, do not work at SHS. Do a review of state medical board license actions & you will see the numerous Corvallis docs who lost their license, were revoked or suspended w/o reinstatement. The physician turnover is huge- ~20% in 5 years. There is a culture of firing-- docs will brag about getting each other fired to other docs.
You will be written up for consulting consultants
You will be written up if you don't smile enough because it's Samaritan so you should be happy.
There is an attitude that Samaritan is the best because so by default- it's their way or the wrong way
Non-medical administrators interfere in care-- CEO of hospital mandated all homeless patients be discharged to placement & not street, then comes back to complain about your length of stay
Many physician admin are just yes-men looking to improve their standing on the corporate ladder
Lots of cliques & inner circles- if you aren't in the right one, you will not get promoted or have your concerns heard
Forget it if you are a DO and not an MD, especially if you did not do an MD residency (except for the residents at their hospital because, you know, it's Samaritan so they must be the best!)
If you had no training at OHSU, you will be seen as a second-glass doctor
Very arrogant & stuck-up culture of you're not good enough for us & we're better than you
Do not work here if you have an accent- they patients & staff will write you up constantly until you lose your accent
Be ready to change yourself for Samaritan or be told to leave
Many older doctors who are close to retirement & either don't care at all or are too controlling & tell you what to do, how to act, what to say, where to park, what street to drive to work, etc
If you are not in the inner circle, you will be made scapegoat in sham peer reviews to take blame for a doc in a clique that made a mistake

pros: The benefits are really good.
cons: You have to move around within the company and not stay more than a couple of years in one office or the office manager will fire you because you cost them too much money and put them over their office budget. This has happened so many times, it's crazy!

pros: Great benefits. Full health insurance. Amazing PTO to be earned.
cons: Too many cooks in the kitchen who don't know how to cook. Tons of micromanagement and too many meetings to get your work done.
